title: How to pay for assistive technology - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m married to an old Information Systems prof, and I have two children who are involved in high tech. So, I don’t pay — except our children weary of being our “go to’s”. And, actually, my husband can almost always figure out how to solve the problem, but it takes far too long. High tech changes so rapidly that it’s a real challenge for older people who’ve spent a lifetime adapting to new technology, now excited to the constant innovations created by the young. We love you because you WORK, and are innovative. Still, we wish there weren’t so very many of you — competing for tech rewards.

Medicare, Medicaid, private health or disability insurance, and worker's compensation may pay for some assistive technology. In most cases, a demonstration of medical necessity for the product or equipment and a prescription from a doctor or other professional will be required.
